choices.text: 10 to 12 weeks
8 to 10 weeks

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.

 

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:

 

  • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • Severe: <7 g%

 

Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia

 

  • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe Anemia

 

  • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 to 12 weeks: While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.

 

Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.

 

Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma


Phacolytic glaucoma occurs when high intraocular pressure (IOP) is associated with a mature or hypermature cataract. The patient's right eye exhibits high IOP (50 mmHg), flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens, all of which are characteristic signs of phacolytic glaucoma. The leakage of lens material into the anterior chamber induces an inflammatory response, causing the observed clinical signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: This condition typically features a shallow or flat anterior chamber, which contrasts with the described deep anterior chamber. Therefore, it is not consistent with the clinical findings of this patient.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: This is usually a unilateral condition characterized by chronic inflammation, heterochromia (differences in iris color), and low-grade inflammation. It does not typically present with such high IOP or a cataractous lens as the primary issue.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: This type of glaucoma occurs due to lens-induced angle closure and is associated with a shallow anterior chamber. The patient, however, has a deep anterior chamber, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

choices.text: Interrupted sutures with delayed re-evaluation
Simple continuous suture with absorbable material

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distension that began earlier in the day. His parents report that he has had similar episodes of abdominal pain and constipation intermittently over the past few months. On examination, his abdomen is markedly distended and tender, particularly in the lower quadrants. Imaging studies suggest a bowel obstruction. During emergency surgery, the surgeon discovers a segment of necrotic small bowel due to a volvulus. What is the most appropriate method for performing the anastomosis after resection of the necrotic bowel?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single-layer extramucosal suture technique

 

Explanation:

 

The single-layer extramucosal suture technique, also known as the Halsted technique, involves placing sutures in the seromuscular layer of the bowel without penetrating the mucosa. This method reduces operative time, minimizes trauma to the bowel, and lowers the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leaks. It is particularly effective in small bowel anastomosis, especially in cases involving compromised bowel tissue, as it enhances healing while maintaining the integrity of the bowel wall.

 

The extramucosal approach is favored in compromised or necrotic bowel conditions because it preserves the bowel’s structural integrity while promoting optimal healing with reduced complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traditional double-layer suture technique: This option is incorrect because the traditional two-layer technique involves suturing both the mucosal and seromuscular layers, which can increase operative time and risk of complications, particularly in fragile or necrotic bowel segments due to excessive tissue handling.

 

Option C. Interrupted sutures with delayed re-evaluation: This option is incorrect because delaying the decision for a complete anastomosis is not advisable when viable tissue is available for primary anastomosis. Immediate, appropriate anastomotic technique should be used to prevent further complications.

 

Option D. Simple continuous suture with absorbable material: This option is incorrect as the simple continuous suture does not specifically target the needs of compromised bowel, and it can increase the risk of anastomotic failure compared to the controlled placement of the single-layer extramucosal suture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method for bowel anastomosis in cases involving necrotic or compromised bowel tissue. This approach minimizes surgical trauma, reduces the risk of postoperative complications, and supports optimal healing, making it a critical choice in managing complex bowel conditions encountered during surgery.

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) QALY

 

Quality Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)

 

  • QALY is a measure of both quality and quantity of life lived
  • QALY is years of life lived in perfect health
  • QALY is used in assessing the value of money of a medical intervention
  • QALY calculation is simple: the change in utility value induced by the treatment is multiplied by the duration of the treatment effect to provide the number of QALYs gained

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HALE: Health-adjusted life expectancy - equivalent number of years in “full health” that a new-born can expect to live based on current rates of ill health and mortality

 

Option B. DALY: Is disability-adjusted life years, which is the best measure of disease burden, including both reduction in life expectancy and diminished quality of life. It can measure both mortality and disability together.

 

DALY = YLL (years of life lost) + YLD (years lost to disability)

 

Option C.  Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy): Means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

 

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is composed of four deoxyribonucleotides, i.e. deoxyadenylate (A), deoxyguanylate (G), deoxycytidylate (C), and thymidylate (T).

 

These units are linked by 3′ to 5′ phosphodiester bonds (covalent bonds) to form a long polypeptide chain. The nucleotide is formed by a combination of base + sugar + phosphoric acid. The 3′-hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5′-hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group.

 

The DNA strands are held together mainly by hydrogen bonds between the purine and pyrimidine bases. There are two hydrogen bonds between Adenine (A) and Thymine (T) while there are three hydrogen bonds between Cytidine (C) and Guanine (G). The GC bond is therefore stronger than the AT bond.

 

The spatial alignment of the helix allows only purine to pyrimidine base pairing.

 

A-T and C-G base pairs have almost the same shape. A mispairing will disturb the stable double helical structure.

 

 

Other interactions contributing to DNA stability include:

 

  • Hydrophobic effects - DNA has an arrangement wherein the non-polar, uncharged bases are present in the interior of the structure, while the negatively charged phosphates are present on the outside. As the cellular environment is aqueous and polar, the hydrophobic bases in the interior of the helix are kept away from the surrounding water and the hydrophilic heads are exposed and interact with the exterior water. This property increases the solubility of DNA in water.
  • Van der Waals forces - The nitrogenous bases stacked upon one another are spaced based on their van der Waals distance. Van der Waals distance is the distance at which two molecules are attracted to each other. If this distance reduces, the electrons of the two molecules may overlap causing repulsion. These forces are very distance dependent and are inversely proportional to the sixth power of distance (r6). Although a single van der Waals interaction has a very small effect on the overall structure of DNA, the net effect of several interactions leads to substantial stability.
  • Ionic interactions - The electrostatic (ion-ion) repulsion of the negatively charged phosphates on the outside can make DNA potentially very unstable. However, magnesium ions (Mg2+) and cationic proteins along with arginine and lysine residues interact with the negatively charged groups in the DNA and stabilize it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. lonic bond: This type of bond occurs between charged atoms (ions), typically in the form of salts and is not involved in the structure of DNA.


Option B. Covalent bond: Covalent bonds are strong bonds formed by sharing electrons between atoms. In DNA, covalent bonds (phosphodiester bonds) link the sugar-phosphate backbone but are not marked in the provided image.

option D. Phosphodiester Bond: This is a covalent bond that forms the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. It is not the bond marked in orange in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text:
Organize the given steps of Karyotyping into the accurate sequence. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days
  4. Harvest with colchicine
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Karyotyping is a process that allows for the visualization of chromosomes in a cell, usually to diagnose genetic diseases, identify chromosomal abnormalities, or analyze chromosomal structures. The accurate sequence for conducting karyotyping involves several key steps, each critical to ensuring accurate results.

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe: Blood is typically drawn from a peripheral vein using a syringe containing heparin, an anticoagulant that prevents blood from clotting, thereby preserving the cells for further processing.
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin: The collected cells, which contain lymphocytes, are then cultured in a medium containing phytohaemoagglutinin (PHA), a mitogen that stimulates lymphocytes to enter mitosis. This step is crucial because chromosomes are most easily visualized and analyzed during mitosis.
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days: The cell culture is incubated at 37 degrees Celsius for approximately 3 days to allow the cells to grow and divide, ensuring a sufficient number of cells reach the metaphase stage of mitosis.
  4. Harvest with colchicine: Colchicine is added to the culture to arrest cells in metaphase by disrupting the mitotic spindle formation. This ensures that a large number of cells are caught in metaphase, where chromosomes are most condensed and visible for karyotyping.
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa: After harvesting, the cells are fixed, dropped onto a slide, and stained with Giemsa stain. This stain provides a distinct banding pattern on the chromosomes, which helps in identifying and analyzing the structure and number of chromosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accurate sequence for conducting Karyotyping is outlined below:

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of low-risk prostatic carcinoma. The most likely management for this patient would be active surveillance only.

  • Active surveillance is a management approach used for prostate cancer with specific criteria.
  • Criteria for active surveillance include Gleason score 6, early-stage disease (T1), small volume disease on biopsy, age > 70 years and low PSA (<10 ng/mL).
  • Active surveillance protocols include regular digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical prostatectomy: This surgical procedure involves removing the entire prostate gland. It is often considered for prostate cancer treatment, especially for younger, healthier patients or those with more aggressive forms of the disease.

 

Option B. External beam radiation: This treatment involves using targeted radiation beams to kill cancer cells. It can be considered for prostate cancer, particularly when surgery is not an option. The choice between radiation therapy and active surveillance depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the stage and aggressiveness of the cancer.

 

Option C. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy where radioactive seeds or sources are placed directly into or near the tumor. It's a localized treatment and can be used for low to intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Again, the decision to use brachytherapy depends on several factors, including the patient's overall health and the characteristics of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels.
  • This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of doom? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iliopubic tract

 

Iliopubic tract does not form a boundary of the triangle of doom.

 

The Iliopubic tract is not a boundary of the Triangle of Doom. It is not directly associated with this anatomical region. It forms the lateral boundary of triangle of pain

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vas deferens: It runs medially and is considered one of the key landmarks in this anatomical region.

 

Option B. Peritoneal Reflection: It forms the inferior boundary of this anatomical triangle.

 

Option D. Spermatic vessels: The spermatic vessels are one of the boundaries of the Triangle of Doom. They are located laterally and are an important landmark in this anatomical triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of doom is bounded-

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

Apex is oriented superiorly at the internal ring

 

The contents of the space are-

 

  • External iliac vessels

 

Note: Staples must be avoided in this region during hernia repair due to the risk of injury to the vessels which might cause severe hemorrhage.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma 

 

  • The patient's presentation with an ulcerative lesion near the nose/medial canthus with rolled out edges is a basal cell carcinoma. 

 

This is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing in sun-exposed areas such as the face. BCC frequently presents as a pearly bump with telangiectatic vessels or as a flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion. Ulceration is common in neglected or advanced BCC, particularly near critical areas like the nose and eyes, where it can cause significant local destruction. Given its common presentation and the description provided, BCC is a very likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo Maligna Melanoma: This is a type of melanoma that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin, particularly the face and the arms, in older adults. It begins as a patch that darkens, enlarges, and sometimes becomes nodular, indicating progression to melanoma. It's less common for lentigo maligna to present initially as an ulcerative lesion, making this a less likely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a type of skin cancer that can also appear on sun-exposed skin and may develop from a pre-existing actinic keratosis. It can be more aggressive than BCC and typically presents as a thick, rough, scaly patch that can bleed if bumped. It can ulcerate but often has a more rapid growth compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus is a common skin growth (mole), which can be present from birth or appear during childhood or young adulthood. While most nevi are benign, changes in their appearance, such as ulceration, require evaluation to rule out malignant transformation, such as into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the description of an ulcerative lesion near critical areas like the nose and medial canthus, Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis due to its frequent occurrence in these regions and its tendency to ulcerate. Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

choices.text: Pain in the calf while walking
Pain in the buttocks while walking

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in the buttocks while walking

 

Explanation:

 

The most frequent symptom of aortoiliac disease is gluteal claudication, which is characterized by pain in the buttocks during walking. This pain occurs due to the location of the blockage in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to reduced blood flow to the buttocks, hips, and thighs.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pain in the calf while walking: This is typically associated with femoropopliteal disease rather than aortoiliac occlusive disease.

 

Option C. Erectile dysfunction: Although impotence can occur in Leriche syndrome, which involves aortoiliac occlusive disease, it is not the most common symptom.

 

Option D. No symptoms at all: While some individuals may be asymptomatic, the most common presentation includes symptoms like gluteal claudication in the case of aortoiliac disease.

 

Educational objectives :

 

The primary symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease is pain in the buttocks while walking, known as gluteal claudication

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in heart rate.

 

An increase in heart rate is the best sign that a ventilatory effort is working.

 

When newborns are unable to breathe on their own, positive pressure ventilation, or PP, is used. To ensure that the airway is open, the infant's neck is slightly stretched in this position. An appropriate-sized face mask is chosen so that it may cover the mouth and nose when the care provider is at the baby's head end. For a good seal, it should be gripped firmly, and compression is applied using the fingers.

 

Visible chest rise is a sign of adequate ventilation, and ventilation should be initiated when normal chest rise is seen.

 

The baby's progress is measured by an increase in heart rate, spontaneous breathing, and improvement in colour.

 

When there is no rise in heart rate, ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows

 

  • Mask has to be reapplied
  • The infant's head is repositioned
  • Suction the secretions
  • The mouth is kept open slightly and ventilated. Also, the pressure is increased slightly.
  • Change the airway

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is a component of APGAR score

 

Option C. Air entry: Air entry is checked during intubation to check weather the endotracheal tube is in centre which gives equal air entry to both lungs.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Chest rise is also seen once we do bag and mask ventilation but the most important indicator is rising heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal resuscitation, rise in heart rate is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort.

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

Explanation

 

Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.

 

Reason for decerebrate rigidity:

 

  • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by

 

  1. γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  2. Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  3. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  4. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.

 

Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

choices.text: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was diagnosed with breast cancer of 1.2 X 1 cm with positive axillary nodes and underwent treatment for the same. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. How will you follow up the patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

 

The most important aspect of breast cancer follow-up is regular surveillance mammograms. Annual mammograms are recommended to monitor for any signs of disease recurrence or new breast cancers. Mammograms are effective in detecting early breast cancer and remain a crucial part of long-term follow-up care for breast cancer survivors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months: Regular liver function testing (LFT) is not typically indicated for breast cancer follow-up. While liver metastases can occur in breast cancer, LFT monitoring is usually reserved for patients on certain medications or with specific clinical indications.

 

Option C. Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months: While tumor markers like CA 15-3 and CA 27.29 can be useful in some cases for monitoring breast cancer, they are not the primary means of follow-up and are not recommended for routine use as they can have limitations in sensitivity and specificity.

 

Option D. Yearly bone scans: Yearly bone scans are not part of routine breast cancer follow-up unless there is clinical suspicion of bone metastases. Performing bone scans annually would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation and costs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of routine physical examination once in 3 months for a year and annual mammogram.

 

Mammography is the only imaging modality required for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. Tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scan currently have no role in follow-up.

 

Guidelines for follow-up:

 

Physical examination:

 

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months
  • After 5 years: Annually

 

Mammography:

 

  • Initially, 6 months after surgery
  • Thereafter, annually.

questions.text: Which of the following suture materials is commonly used in neurosurgery and microsurgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nylon

 

Nylon is a non-absorbable suture material and is commonly used in neurosurgery, microsurgery, and ophthalmic surgery due to its low tissue reaction and high tensile strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyglactin: Polyglactin (Vicryl) is an absorbable braided suture material and is commonly used in general surgical practices for gut anastomoses, vascular ligatures, subcuticular wound closures, and ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option C. Polypropylene 1-0 & Option D. Polypropylene 2-0: Polypropylene is a non-absorbable suture material and is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair. Polypropylene 1-0 and 2-0 refer to the size or diameter of the suture, with 1-0 being larger than 2-0. These sutures are too thick to be used in microsurgery.

 

Therefore, options B, C, and D are incorrect as they do not match the given description.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a slowly enlarging, reddish nodule on her left thigh that she first noticed about six months ago. The lesion has been painless and stable in size, causing her no discomfort. Physical examination reveals a firm, well-defined, non-tender reddish nodule. A biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination is shown in the images provided. Based on the clinical presentation and histological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemangioma

 

Explanation:

 

A hemangioma is a benign tumor that results from an abnormal proliferation of blood vessels. Histopathologically, hemangiomas are well-circumscribed lesions composed of thin-walled, dilated blood vessels. The vessels are lined with flattened, uniform endothelial cells with minimal mitotic activity, indicating a benign nature. The vessels are often organized into lobules, separated by stromal cells such as fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and pericytes. In cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels appear larger and more dilated compared to the smaller vessels seen in capillary hemangiomas. These histological features help distinguish hemangiomas from other vascular and soft tissue tumors.

 

Histopathological Features: Hemangiomas display lobules of dilated vessels, a well-circumscribed appearance, and uniform endothelial cells, confirming their benign vascular nature and differentiating them from other similar lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyogenic granuloma: This option is incorrect because pyogenic granulomas are rapidly growing, friable lesions that often bleed easily. Histologically, they show a proliferation of capillary-sized vessels within an edematous stroma, which is distinct from the more organized lobular vascular structure of a hemangioma.

 

Option C. Glomus tumor: This option is incorrect because glomus tumors typically present as painful nodules under the fingernails or other subungual locations. Histology shows nests of glomus cells surrounding blood vessels, differing significantly from the purely vascular structure seen in hemangiomas.

 

Option D. Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP): This option is incorrect because DFSP typically presents as a firm, flesh-colored to reddish nodule with a slow but invasive growth pattern. Histologically, it shows a storiform pattern of spindle cells, unlike the well-circumscribed vascular appearance of hemangiomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors characterized by well-circumscribed lesions composed of lobules of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels lined with uniform endothelial cells. Recognizing these histopathological features is essential for differentiating hemangiomas from other vascular lesions and guiding appropriate management.

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Infertility
  2. Dysmenorrhea
  3. Vaginal discharge
  4. Vaginal bleeding
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside the uterus. This condition is associated with specific symptoms:

 

1. Infertility: Women with endometriosis often experience difficulty conceiving. The presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus can interfere with the reproductive organs, leading to infertility.

 

2. Dysmenorrhea: Painful menstruation is a hallmark of endometriosis. This condition can cause severe menstrual cramps due to the endometrial tissue responding to hormonal changes as it would in a normal menstrual cycle.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 3, 4: Vaginal discharge and vaginal bleeding are not characteristic symptoms of endometriosis. Vaginal discharge may be seen in various other conditions but is not specific to endometriosis. Similarly, while endometriosis can cause abnormal bleeding, it typically presents with pain rather than increased vaginal bleeding.

 

Option B. 2, 3: While dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) is a symptom of endometriosis, vaginal discharge is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Dysmenorrhea is indeed a symptom of endometriosis, but increased vaginal bleeding is not a primary symptom of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis commonly presents with symptoms including dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and infertility.


Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: While performing triage of children who are victims of a school bus accident, which one will you attend to first? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Airway Obstruction

 

The most appropriate answer is airway obstruction.

 

Maintaining a patent airway is crucial for the survival of any trauma patient, especially children. An airway obstruction can quickly lead to severe respiratory distress and, if left untreated, can result in death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 4 Shock: While shock is a critical condition, attending to airway obstruction takes precedence because it directly impacts oxygenation, which is vital for life. Treating shock without addressing airway obstruction may not be effective.

 

Option C. Flail Chest: Flail chest is a serious chest injury, but it may not be an immediate threat to the airway. It should be assessed and treated promptly but is not the first priority compared to airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Severe head injury: Head injuries are also critical, but immediate attention to airway obstruction is necessary to ensure the child's ability to breathe and maintain oxygenation. Head injuries can be assessed and managed after ensuring a clear airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage decisions are to be made by deciding which injuries constitute the greatest immediate threat to life.

 

In general, airway problems are more rapidly lethal than breathing problems › circulation problems > neurologic injuries.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a postoperative image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image below ? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch stitch

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.
  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal.
  • It is now rarely done due to postoperative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device. This procedure does not align with the provided image of Thiersch wiring.

 

Option B. Well's procedure: An abdominal procedure for rectal prolapse that involves repositioning and attaching the rectum to the sacrum using sutures, often reinforced with mesh. This technique does not correspond to the image provided, which clearly shows a perineal approach with wiring.

 

Option D. Altemeier repair: A perineal approach to resect and anastomose the prolapsed rectum. While Altemeier repair is a perineal procedure, it involves resection and anastomosis rather than the placement of a circumferential wire around the anus, as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiersch's procedure, involving the placement of a wire or tape around the anal canal, is used in managing rectal prolapse but is now infrequently performed due to associated complications such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones. To enhance visualization of the gallbladder and reduce the risk of aspiration during the procedure, the patient is positioned as shown in the image. This position is often used in upper abdominal surgeries to facilitate better access to the surgical field. What is the name of the patient position depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reverse Trendelenburg

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates the Reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient’s head is elevated 15-30 degrees above the feet. This positioning is particularly beneficial during upper abdominal surgeries as it allows abdominal organs to move downward, away from the diaphragm, improving access to the surgical site. In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the Reverse Trendelenburg position, sometimes combined with a slight left tilt, aids in exposing the gallbladder by retracting its fundus towards the diaphragm. This orientation not only enhances the surgical view but also minimizes the risk of aspiration during anesthesia. Restraints and sideboards are often used to prevent the patient from sliding off the table, ensuring safety during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trendelenburg: This option is incorrect because the Trendelenburg position tilts the patient with the head down and feet elevated, increasing venous return and often used in shock or to improve access to the lower abdomen and pelvis, but it compromises exposure of the upper abdominal organs.

 

 

Option C. Fowler’s: This option is incorrect because Fowler’s position involves a semi-sitting posture with the back elevated. It is primarily used for patients with respiratory distress or during recovery, and does not specifically improve access to the upper abdomen during surgery.

 

 

 

Option D. Supine: This option is incorrect because the supine position involves the patient lying flat on the back without any elevation of the head or feet. It does not provide the enhanced visualization or access required for upper abdominal surgeries like cholecystectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Reverse Trendelenburg position is widely used in upper abdominal surgeries, such as laparoscopic cholecystectomy, to improve surgical exposure by shifting the abdominal organs downward, away from the diaphragm. This positioning facilitates better access to the surgical field and reduces the risk of aspiration, making it essential for optimizing patient safety and surgical outcomes.

choices.text: Hairy cell leukemia
Follicular lymphoma
AML M7

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will have the least chances of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular lymphoma

 

Follicular lymphoma is the least likely cause of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration.

 

A "dry tap" occurs when bone marrow aspiration fails to yield adequate marrow material, usually due to the marrow being fibrotic, densely packed with cells, or infiltrated by abnormal cells. This can occur in various hematologic conditions where the bone marrow architecture is disrupted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hairy cell leukemia: This condition often causes extensive marrow fibrosis and infiltration by malignant cells, making bone marrow aspiration difficult, thus increasing the likelihood of a dry tap.

 

Option C. AML M7 (Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia): This subtype of acute myeloid leukemia is associated with marrow fibrosis, which can result in a dry tap during bone marrow aspiration.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): Some subtypes of MDS can cause fibrosis and hypercellularity, leading to a higher likelihood of a dry tap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of dry tap are:

 

  • Faulty technique
  • Metastatic carcinoma infiltration
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Myelofibrosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Acute leukemia
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • AML- M7

choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

 

Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

 

The autosomal dominant condition known as Huntington disease (HD) is characterized histologically by the destruction of striatal neurons and clinically by increasing mobility abnormalities and dementia. All portions of the body move jerkily, hyperkinetically, and occasionally in a dystonic manner (chorea); affected people may eventually develop parkinsonism with bradykinesia and stiffness. The average course of the illness is around 15 years before death because of its persistent progression.

 

The polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat expansion illnesses have their origins in Huntington disease. The HD gene, which is found on chromosome 4p16.3, produces the 348-kD huntingtin protein.

 

A section of CAG repeats in the gene's first exon encodes a polyglutamine region near the protein's N terminus. The repeat is present in 6 to 35 copies in normal HD genes; when the number of repeats is increased beyond this level it is associated with disease.

 

There is an inverse relationship between repeat number and age of onset, such that longer repeats are associated with earlier onset.

 

The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. There is loss of function type of mutation: This is incorrect. Huntington's disease is caused by a gain-of-function mutation due to the expansion of the CAG repeat in the huntingtin gene, not by a loss-of-function mutation.

 

Option C. There are abnormal repeats of CUG: This is incorrect. The trinucleotide repeat involved in Huntington's disease is CAG, not CUG. CUG repeats are associated with other genetic disorders, such as myotonic dystrophy.

 

Option D. Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6: This is incorrect. The genetic mutation causing Huntington's disease is located on chromosome 4p16.3, not chromosome 6.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically seen in MEN-1 syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior pituitary tumors

 

Explanation:

 

MEN type 1 (MEN 1), also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary. Tumors in the posterior pituitary are not associated with MEN-1. Other features of MEN-1 include adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors (usually of the foregut), meningiomas, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, and lipomas. The most common endocrine abnormalities in MEN-1 are multiglandular parathyroid tumors, leading to hyperparathyroidism. Hypercalcemia is often the first biochemical abnormality detected in MEN-1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are the second most common manifestation, and prolactinomas are the most common pituitary tumors  in MEN-1.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors: These are a common manifestation of MEN-1, often nonfunctioning or secreting pancreatic polypeptides. Functional NETs like gastrinomas and insulinomas are also seen.

 

Option C. Foregut carcinoid: Carcinoid tumors, typically of the foregut, can occur in patients with MEN-1.

 

Option D. Parathyroid hyperplasia:  Multiglandular parathyroid tumors are the most common endocrine abnormality in MEN-1, leading to hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational objectives :

 

MEN-1 syndrome includes tumors of the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary, but not the posterior pituitary.

questions.text: In triage, immediately life-threatening injury is categorized as what color code? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In the triage system, which is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code. This indicates that the patient requires immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications. The Red category is the highest priority in triage, where intervention is needed within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green: This color code is used for ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment.

 

Option C. Yellow: The Yellow category is for urgent cases where intervention is required within 6 to 24 hours. While these patients need prompt attention, their condition is not as immediately critical as those in the Red category.

 

Option D. Black: The Black category is reserved for patients who are either deceased or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive). This represents the lowest priority in triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code, indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.

choices.text: Opening of calcium channels

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Explanation

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

 

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NO: Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline: Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.

choices.text: No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

 

No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination: The resident's serology shows that HBsAg is negative and Anti-HBs is greater than 105 mIU/ml, which indicates that he has sufficient immunity against Hepatitis B from prior vaccination. No further treatment is necessary because the antibody titres are already protective.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Booster dose of vaccine: Not required since the resident already has sufficient antibody levels indicating immunity.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin with full vaccination: This would be necessary if the resident had low or no detectable antibody titres, indicating no prior immunity.

 

Option C. Repeat full course of vaccine: Not necessary because the resident already has adequate antibody titres indicating immunity.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: In a case of fatality resulting from firearm injuries, the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar. The firearm's firing distance probably is? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distant range

 

An abrasion collar is a ring of abraded skin around the entrance wound of a bullet. It is caused by the bullet's friction as it penetrates the skin. This feature can be found at any distance, including distant range. However, additional features such as singeing, blackening, and tattooing are present only at closer ranges. Since the question states that the entrance wound displays solely an abrasion collar, it indicates that none of the other close-range features are present, suggesting a distant range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact range: At contact range, there would be singeing, blackening, and tattooing right at the margins of the wound, as well as potential muzzle imprint and burning due to the close proximity of the firearm.

 

Option B. Close range: At close range, there would be significant blackening and tattooing around the wound, indicating the firearm was discharged from a short distance but not in contact with the skin.

 

Option C. Near range: At near range, there would still be some blackening and tattooing around the wound, but these features diminish with increasing distance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are five features of firearm entry wound (inner most to outermost):

 

  • Grease Collar (inner most)
  • Abrasion collar
  • Singeing
  • Blackening
  • Tattooing (outer most)

 

Out of these five features, Abrasion collar and Grease collar can be found in any entry wound, irrespective of the distance between victim and firearm. This is because these are produced by bullet itself as it enters the body.

 

Whereas Singeing, Blackening and Tattooing occur only upto a limited distance

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Induration

 

ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration.

 

ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

 

ASEPSIS SCORE

 

 

Criterion Not Included: 

 

Option D. Induration: Induration (hardening of the tissue) is not included in the ASEPSIS wound scoring system. The criteria focus on discharge, erythema, separation of tissues, bacterial isolation, and additional treatments rather than tissue induration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ASEPSIS wound scoring system does not include induration as a criterion. It focuses on factors like purulent and serous discharge, erythema, separation of deep tissue, additional treatments, bacterial isolation, and extended hospital stay to evaluate surgical site infections.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Labia majora - separated
  • Labia minora- flabby
  • Fourchette tear present
  • Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen

 

What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False virgin

 

The observed separated labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not a virgin. Despite having sexual intercourse, the hymen is intact so it is a case of false virgin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True virgin: Presence of labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not true virgin.

 

Option C. Premenstrual change typically involve hormonal variations leading to breast tenderness, bloating, and mood swings rather than observable alterations in genital anatomy.

 

Option D. Molestation there would be sign of abrasions, bruising, edema, laceration or may have injuries to the vulva, hymen, vagina and the perineum. Since these signs are not present chances of molestation are slim

 

Educational  Objective:

 

Please note that the features will be same for a deflorate woman and a false virgin with the exception of presence of hymen in the latter.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed

 

The image displays a Romovac drain placed after mastectomy, which is a closed-type drain. Drains are utilized at surgical sites to collect air or fluid buildup, promoting wound healing by preventing cavity formation. Drains can be prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries, with open, semi-open, and closed types.

 

They carry out their actions through suction

 

  • Eg. Romovac drain, Jackson Pratt drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open: They are based on the principle of gravity or capillary effect

 

  • Eg. Corrugated drain, Foley’s catheter etc.\

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Romovac drain is a closed negative suction drain placed in subcutaneous tissue and indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. Other specialized drains include chest drains for air removal from the pleural cavity and T-tubes for bile drainage after surgical exploration of the bile duct.

questions.text: How is wound infection severity graded? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southampton grading

 

Southampton wound grading system is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection.

 

  • The Southampton Wound Grading System is a widely recognized method for grading wound infection severity.
  • It categorizes surgical site infections (SSI) into different grades based on clinical signs, such as erythema (redness), purulent discharge, and wound breakdown.
  • The grading system allows healthcare providers to classify SSIs as minor, moderate, or severe based on specific criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASA classification: The ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification system is primarily used to assess a patient's overall health and fitness for surgery.

 

  • It does not directly grade wound infection severity.

 

Option B. SIRS criteria (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome): SIRS criteria are used to identify systemic inflammation and are not specific to grading wound infection severity.

 

  • These criteria include parameters like temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and white blood cell count.

 

Option D. APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II): The APACHE II score is a severity of illness scoring system used to assess critically ill patients in intensive care units.

 

  • It does not directly relate to grading wound infection severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southampton grading:

 

 

In summary, the Southampton grading system is the appropriate option for grading wound infection severity as it provides a structured approach to categorizing surgical site infections based on clinical criteria. This system helps healthcare providers assess the seriousness of wound infections and make appropriate treatment decisions.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of persistent fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold temperatures, and unexplained weight gain over the past year. He also reports experiencing dry skin, muscle cramps, and constipation. On physical examination, the physician notes coarse, dry skin, mild swelling around the eyes, and a slightly enlarged but non-tender thyroid gland. Laboratory results reveal an elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and a low free thyroxine (T4) level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's constellation of symptoms of fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, dry skin, constipation, and muscle cramps  is highly suggestive of hypothyroidism. The elevated TSH level and low free T4 level confirm this diagnosis. Furthermore, the presence of a slightly enlarged thyroid gland (goiter) points toward Hashimoto's thyroiditis, an autoimmune condition that is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. In Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland, leading to its gradual destruction and decreased thyroid hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pituitary insufficiency: This would lead to central hypothyroidism, characterized by low or inappropriately normal TSH levels, which is not consistent with this patient's elevated TSH.

 

Option C. Euthyroid sick syndrome: This condition is typically seen in critically ill patients and is characterized by abnormal thyroid function tests without true thyroid dysfunction. It is not associated with the classic hypothyroid symptoms this patient is experiencing.

 

Option D. Iodine deficiency goiter: While iodine deficiency can cause hypothyroidism and goiter, it is less common in developed countries where iodine intake is generally sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It presents with elevated TSH, low T4, and a constellation of symptoms related to hypothyroidism. Early recognition and diagnosis are crucial for proper management.

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain, whose elder brother passed away due to stroke at the age of 40 and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and the ultrasound image provided suggest the diagnosis of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys. Over time, these cysts can enlarge and decrease the functioning of the kidneys, leading to kidney failure.
  • Besides renal symptoms, patients with ADPKD can have other complications, such as cerebral aneurysms (which can rupture leading to strokes), liver cysts, and cardiac valvular diseases.
  • The combination of multiple episodes of hematuria, hypertension, familial history, and the ultrasound findings make this diagnosis the most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. It originates from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It may present with hematuria, pain in the flank or loin area, and a palpable abdominal mass. However, the familial context, with the brother's early death from a stroke, doesn't typically fit with the presentation of RCC. RCC occurs in an elderly age group.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis of the kidney: Tuberculosis (TB) can affect the kidneys, usually as a secondary site from pulmonary TB. This can lead to a chronic inflammatory response. Kidney TB might present with sterile pyuria (white blood cells in urine without bacterial growth), hematuria, and even systemic symptoms of TB like fever, weight loss, and night sweats. The clinical scenario provided doesn't specifically lean toward this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): ARPKD is another inherited form of polycystic kidney disease. However, it's different from ADPKD in that it presents much earlier, usually in childhood or infancy. Symptoms in ARPKD are typically severe and can include kidney failure and liver problems at a young age.

 

  • Given the combination of clinical symptoms, family history, and ultrasound findings, the most probable diagnosis in this scenario is option B, Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is an inherited disorder characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure, hypertension, and a higher risk of cerebral aneurysms, making it crucial to consider family history and typical ultrasound findings in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in managing this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrograffin follow-through

 

The given clinical history along with the radiograph showing the triple bubble sign implies a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. A contrast study should be the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies.

 

A Gastrograffin follow-through is a radiological procedure that involves the administration of contrast material (Gastrograffin) followed by a series of X-rays to visualize the gastrointestinal tract. An alternate investigation would be CT with contrast (not given in options). In cases of recurrent bilious vomiting, it is a valuable diagnostic tool to assess for intestinal obstruction, such as malrotation or other anatomical abnormalities. It helps determine if there are any blockages or abnormalities in the intestines that may be causing the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Performing an endoscopy is generally not the first-line investigation for a neonate with recurrent bilious vomiting where an obstructive GI pathology is likely.

 

Option C. USG abdomen: An ultrasound (USG) of the abdomen can provide useful information in some cases, but it may not be the most appropriate initial investigation for recurrent bilious vomiting when there is a need to evaluate the entire gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Explorative laparotomy: Explorative laparotomy, which involves surgery to explore the abdominal cavity, is a more invasive option and is typically considered when other diagnostic methods have failed to provide a clear diagnosis or when there is a strong suspicion of a surgical emergency. It is not the first-line choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small bowel atresia’s present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth.

 

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent with ileal atresia.

 

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed despite the atresia.

 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction

 

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is performed. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

questions.text: All are long acting reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

 

Explanation:

 

Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:

 

  • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.

 

Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 491-492,479,

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 11

 

The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

11 number blade is used In stab incisions needed when lancing an abscess or inserting a chest drain and in skin incisions and arteriotomy

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two or more of the following criteria are present: hyperthermia or hypothermia, Tachypnea or low PaCO2, Tachycardia, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic blood pressure is not included in the SIRS criteria. Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented infection.

 

This is not a criterion for SIRS. SIRS criteria typically include fever or hypothermia, tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute), tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute), and abnormal white blood cell count. Low blood pressure is more related to septic shock, which can be a consequence of severe sepsis but is not one of the primary criteria for SIRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius: This is a criterion for SIRS.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 bpm: This is a criterion for SIRS. Elevated respiratory rate (>20 breaths per minute) or paCO2 < 32 mm of Hg is one of the criteria used to diagnose SIRS.

 

Option D. Heart rate >90 min: This is a criterion for SIRS. Tachycardia, defined as a heart rate greater than 90 beats per minute, is one of the key criteria for SIRS.

 

In summary, Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg (option A) is not a criterion for SIRS, while the other options (B, C, and D) are all criteria for SIRS.

choices.text: First assessment with sonography in trauma
Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.text: The acronym FAST refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focused assessment with sonography in trauma

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma and is a non-invasive, rapid bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen.
  • It is used to evaluate patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries and can be performed within 2-4 minutes.
  • The subxiphoid transverse view is used to assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries.
  • The longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant is used to assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch.
  • The longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant is used to assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • The transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region are used to assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.
  • eFAST is an extended version of FAST that incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax.

questions.text: What is the next best step in the management of a 16-year-old male with a painless large round firm right testicular swelling, with a dragging sensation and AFP around 5000? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

 

Testicular mass with elevated AFP is suggestive of testicular tumor, where the next best step in management for this patient is High inguinal orchidectomy

 

This is the correct choice for the initial management of a suspected malignant testicular tumor. The inguinal approach ensures that the scrotal skin and potential lymphatic drainage are not violated. This procedure allows for both definitive diagnosis (through histopathological examination) and therapeutic management by removing the tumor. An elevated AFP further supports the possibility of a germ cell tumor, such as a yolk sac tumor or non-seminomatous germ cell tumor, both of which warrant surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): While FNAC is a diagnostic procedure, it's not typically used in the primary evaluation of testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding along the needle track and is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Scrotal trucut biopsy: This is not recommended for suspected testicular tumors. Biopsying a testicular tumor through a scrotal approach can risk tumor spillage or seeding within the scrotum and can alter the lymphatic drainage pattern, thus complicating future treatment..

 

Option D. Repeat Tumor markers: While monitoring tumor markers like AFP is useful in the management and follow-up of testicular cancer, simply repeating the test without addressing the testicular mass would not be appropriate. The clinical findings and elevated AFP already provide strong evidence of malignancy, and action should be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A painless testicular swelling in a young male with elevated AFP is highly suggestive of a testicular malignancy. The standard of care in such cases is to proceed with a high inguinal orchidectomy for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

choices.text: Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition.
Nuclear characteristics are used for identification.
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. Upon examination, cervical node enlargement is also observed. Histopathological analysis of the lesion reveals the following findings Identify the false statement of the following?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

 

  • The histopathological findings provided are indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which includes features such as papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, distinct orphan Annie nuclei, and psammoma bodies.
  • Fine needle aspiration cytology is actually a common and reliable diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma.
  • By extracting cells from the thyroid nodule using a fine needle and examining them under a microscope, the presence of characteristic features of papillary carcinoma can be identified.
  •  Thus, the statement suggesting that FNAC is not diagnostic is false

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition: This statement refers to the typical prognosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary carcinoma, although malignant, is often slow-growing. When detected early and treated appropriately, patients generally have an excellent prognosis with a high survival rate.

 

Option B. It spreads via lymphatics: While papillary carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatics to regional lymph nodes (leading to cervical node enlargement, as seen in the patient), it typically does so at a slow rate. It's important to note that even when there is lymph node involvement, the prognosis still remains relatively favorable compared to other types of thyroid cancers.

 

Option C. Nuclear characteristics are used for identification: The nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma are characteristic and aid in its identification. One such feature is the "orphan Annie eye" nuclei, which are large, empty-appearing nuclei. Other characteristics, like psammoma bodies, can also be present.

 

  • Given the context and the provided image findings indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, FNAC is indeed diagnostic for this condition. Hence, option D is the false statement among the ones provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a reliable and commonly used diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma, as it can identify characteristic histopathological features.

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.
Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.
