Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

 

Laparoscopic surgeries have become popular as they result in lesser post-operative pain, are cosmetically better, and result in an earlier return to normal physiological function (Options A, B, and C). Patients are discharged from the hospital earlier, with a lower incidence of complications, as compared to open surgeries. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer, as it is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

This statement is incorrect. Laparoscopic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays compared to traditional open surgery. Patients typically spend less time in the hospital and recover faster, which is one of the key advantages of this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain: Smaller incisions and less tissue trauma typically result in less post-operative pain compared to traditional open surgery.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions: This is an advantage of laparoscopic surgery. The smaller incisions are not only cosmetically appealing but also result in reduced scarring and a lower risk of wound infections.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function: Patients often recover more quickly and can resume their normal activities sooner due to the minimally invasive nature of the procedure.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with a hard painless testicular swelling. There were no inguinal, intra-abdominal or mediastinal lymph nodes on CT scan. The blood workup showed AFP levels of > 3000. USG shows uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis. The next line of management is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High inguinal orchidectomy  

 

This is the correct choice. In a young male presenting with a hard, painless testicular swelling and significantly elevated AFP levels (>3000), along with findings of uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis on ultrasound (USG), there is a high suspicion of testicular cancer, particularly a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT). High inguinal orchidectomy is the standard initial surgical approach for the diagnosis and treatment of testicular cancer. The removed testicle is sent for pathological examination to confirm the diagnosis and determine the specific type of tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Core needle trucut biopsy: Core needle biopsy is contraindicate for testicular masses because it carries the risk of tumor spread or seeding along the biopsy tract.

 

Option C. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): FNAC is also not the preferred option for testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding and difficulties in obtaining an accurate diagnosis for testicular cancer.

 

Option D. Whole body PET/CT: Whole body PET/CT is typically used for staging and evaluating the extent of cancer after a diagnosis is confirmed. It is not the initial step in diagnosing a testicular mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given features that point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) in stage I of the tumor. In a case of painless swelling of the testis, a testicular tumor should be suspected. The associated rise in AFP level points toward a diagnosis of NSGCT although tissue diagnosis is required to confirm the nature of the tumor. But tissue diagnosis is not a prerequisite for treatment, and hence, based on the available evidence a high inguinal orchidectomy is done in this case. Further treatment is followed up based on the findings of the excisional biopsy.

 

  • NSGCTs are not radiosensitive, but they are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). Up to 30% of NSGCT patients with stage I disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse if surveillance alone is done after orchidectomy.
  • Accordingly, some NSGCTs with good prognoses can be managed by surveillance protocols (using regular CT scanning and tumor marker measurement), with the more high-risk cases receiving chemotherapy.
  • For NSGCTs a 5-year survival rate of more than 90% is achievable in patients with good prognosis tumors, while for more advanced tumors, the 5-year survival rate is about 60%.

choices.text: By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

questions.text: The adjoining graph shows the effect of PTH on blood calcium and phosphate in an experimental animal. How does PTH increase plasma calcium? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) By increasing osteoclastic activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

 

Explanation:

 

PTH increases calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing the kidneys' excretion of calcium, effectively increasing plasma calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By increasing osteoclast activity: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates osteoclasts indirectly, leading to increased bone resorption, which releases calcium into the bloodstream.

 

Option B. By increasing osteoblastic activity: While PTH does stimulate osteoblasts, this action is primarily to produce RANKL, a cytokine that activates osteoclasts, not to build new bone.

 

Option C. By decreasing renal excretion: PTH reduces calcium excretion by the kidneys, increasing reabsorption of calcium in the renal tubules, contributing to higher blood calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases plasma calcium levels by promoting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and reducing renal excretion of calcium.

questions.text: Locally advanced breast cancer can be defined as all except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor more than 4 cm

 

While a tumor size larger than 4 cm is indicative of a relatively large tumor, it alone does not define locally advanced breast cancer. Locally advanced breast cancer typically involves not only tumor size but also the extent of its spread to nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inflammatory breast cancer: Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive subtype of breast cancer characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth in the breast. It is considered an advanced stage of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Chest wall involvement: Locally advanced breast cancer is often defined by its involvement of the chest wall. This means that the cancer has spread beyond the breast tissue and may affect the underlying muscles and structures of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Skin involvement: Skin involvement, such as changes in the appearance of the skin over the breast like peau’d orange or ulceration, can be a feature of locally advanced breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor more than 5 cm, not 4 is classified as LABC.

 

Locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) includes: (Mnemonic – CUBE N2)

 

C - Chest wall invasion

 

U - Ulceration of skin

 

B - Both (chest wall invasion and ulceration of skin)

 

E - E(I)nflammatory carcinoma

 

N2 - fixed axillary lymph nodes

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Does not provide multiple doses
﻿﻿﻿Drug deposition in the oropharynx

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug deposition in the oropharynx

 

The given image shows a metered-dose inhaler (MDI). It is a common device used for delivering drugs (like inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators etc.) used in the management of bronchial asthma and COPD.

 

Drug Deposition in the Oropharynx is a well-recognized limitation of MDIs. A significant proportion of the medication can deposit in the oropharynx and upper airways instead of reaching the lower respiratory tract where it is needed. This not only reduces the efficiency of the drug delivery to the lungs but can also increase the risk of local side effects, such as oral thrush when using corticosteroid inhalers.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Bacterial Contamination: While good hygiene is important in the maintenance of any inhaler device, bacterial contamination is not a commonly cited primary drawback of MDIs. Regular cleaning can typically manage this risk.

 

Options B. Does Not Provide Multiple Doses: This is not accurate. MDIs are designed to provide multiple doses. They contain a pressurized canister that delivers a specific dose of medication in aerosol form with each actuation.

 

Options D. Not Portable: MDIs are actually very portable and convenient, which is one of their advantages. They are compact and easy to carry, making them suitable for use on the go.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common drawback of metered-dose inhalers (MDIs) is drug deposition in the oropharynx, which reduces the efficiency of drug delivery to the lungs and can increase the risk of local side effects.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient undergoes parotidectomy surgery to remove a tumor. During the postoperative period, the patient complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great auricular nerve

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (specifically, the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the earlobe and the skin over the parotid gland. Damage to this nerve during parotidectomy surgery can lead to loss of sensation in the earlobe area, which could affect the patient's sensation while shaving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the external ear and the temporal region, which if injured gives rise to gustatory sweating or Frey’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Facial nerve: The facial nerve is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression, not sensation. Damage to the facial nerve during parotidectomy surgery can result in facial weakness or paralysis rather than altered sensation.

 

Option D. Marginal mandibular nerve: The marginal mandibular nerve is a branch of the facial nerve and primarily provides innervation to the lower lip. It is not typically involved in sensation during shaving.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nerves that can be injured in parotidectomy and its significance:

 

A) Auriculotemporal nerve injury – Frey’s syndrome

 

B) Great auricular nerve- loss of sensation in area of shaving

 

C) Facial nerve- facial palsy

questions.text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and acute right lower abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 106 beats/min. Tenderness was felt in right iliac fossa. The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following signs will not be seen in this disease? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ballance sign

 

The patient's history and CT findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign is not seen in acute appendicitis.

 

Ballance's sign is seen in splenic trauma, where dullness is seen on right flank on percussion, which doesn’t shift on lateral position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McBurney's tenderness: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus.

 

Option B. Rovsing sign: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa causes pain in the right iliac fossa.

 

Option C. Psoas sign: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Sometimes, the inflamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip flexed, for pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include:

 

  • Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter)
  • Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation 

 

  • In a neonate presenting with a scaphoid abdomen, certain respiratory interventions need to be carefully considered due to the high risk of underlying conditions like congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). 

 

This is contraindicated in neonates with a scaphoid abdomen suspected of having CDH. The use of positive pressure from bag and mask ventilation can exacerbate the displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through the diaphragmatic defect, potentially worsening respiratory distress and leading to further compromise of pulmonary function. This method of ventilation can increase the risk of pneumothorax, gastric distention, and further reduce lung volume, which is already compromised in CDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation): Like intubation, IPPV is used via a mechanical ventilator after intubation and can provide controlled and safe respiratory support. It is also appropriate in these scenarios to ensure that airway pressure is managed carefully to avoid exacerbating the hernia.

 

Option C. Intubation: This is the preferred method for securing the airway in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen when CDH is suspected. Intubation allows for controlled ventilation settings, minimizes gastric distension, and helps manage the baby’s respiratory status more effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

The given scenario and image is most likely to be of Fournier gangrene which is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

 

FOURNIER’S GANGRENE

 

  • Synergistic gangrene of scrotum and perineum
  • Limited to skin and fascial planes - type of necrotising fasciitis
  • Never breaches the tunica, testis always spared
  • Risk factors - Low immunity, uncontrolled diabetes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases: Anti-gas gangrene serum is obsolete now.

 

Option B. Urinary diversion is the next step: Urinary diversion is not the next best step.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done: Testes are preserved during debridement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

choices.text: Conservative management with hydration and antibiotics

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe left-sided flank pain, nausea, and fever for two days. He has a history of recurrent kidney stones and frequent urinary tract infections. Physical exam reveals tenderness over the left costovertebral angle. Laboratory findings show an elevated white blood cell count, and urinalysis reveals significant hematuria and pyuria. A non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen demonstrates a large, complex stone (>4 cm) occupying the left renal pelvis and extending into the calyces. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL)

 

Explanation:

 

PCNL is the gold standard for treating large or complex renal stones, especially those larger than 2 cm or staghorn calculi, as seen in this case. It involves creating a small incision in the back to access the kidney directly, allowing for effective stone fragmentation and removal. This approach minimizes complications and offers a high stone-free rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conservative management: While hydration and antibiotics are important for managing associated infection and pain, they are not sufficient for large, complex stones like this one. Definitive stone removal is necessary to prevent complications.

 

Option C. Open surgical nephrolithotomy: This invasive approach is rarely used as a first-line treatment due to its associated morbidity and longer recovery time. PCNL is less invasive and equally effective for large stones.

 

Option D. Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS): This is more suitable for smaller stones or those in less complex locations within the kidney. It may not be effective for managing large staghorn calculi due to limited access and the inability to handle a large stone burden.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PCNL is the preferred management for large or complex renal stones, such as staghorn calculi. It allows for direct access to the kidney, facilitates effective removal of large stone burdens, and significantly reduces the risk of complications associated with untreated stones.

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

 

  • The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver is suggestive of hydatid disease with floating membrane sign.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog tapeworm.
  • MC site of hydatid cyst in human: liver (MC) followed by pulmonary hydatids (2nd MC)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgery is mandatory: Surgical treatment of hydatid cyst indicated when PAIR is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic: FNAC is contra-indicated as rupture of cyst may lead to spillage or anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice:  Angioembolization has no role in the management of hydatid cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  •  The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  •  FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will be first visualized to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cecum

 

The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.

 

Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.

 

Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periampullary carcinoma

 

The most probable diagnosis in this patient is periampullary carcinoma.

 

Here are the characteristic features of periampullary carcinoma:

 

  • Arises from the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater
  • Presents with jaundice that intermittently waxes and wanes due to partial relief of obstruction to bile ducts whenever the tumor undergoes necrosis and sloughing
  • Other symptoms include weight loss, pain, nausea, vomiting, pruritus, fever, and gastrointestinal bleeding
  • A three-phase CT scan is recommended for diagnosis- which shows double duct sign (dilated CBD and pancreatic duct).
  • Management includes resection, along with chemotherapy/chemoradiotherapy

 

Periampullary carcinoma refers to cancers that arise in the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater, where the bile duct and pancreatic duct converge before entering the duodenum. These tumors can obstruct both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, leading to intermittent or waxing and waning jaundice. The anatomical location of periampullary carcinomas and double duct sign on CT makes them a likely cause in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocarcinoma: Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that originates in the bile ducts. While it can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically presents with a more gradual and progressive course of symptoms. It may cause dilatation of the bile ducts, but waxing and waning jaundice is less characteristic of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Common bile duct stone: While a common bile duct stone can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically leads to a more acute presentation with sudden onset of symptoms. Waxing and waning jaundice is not a common feature of common bile duct stones.

 

Option D. Head of pancreas carcinoma: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, also known as pancreatic head carcinoma, can obstruct the common bile duct and cause jaundice. However, it tends to present with a more persistent and progressive form of jaundice rather than waxing and waning symptoms, as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periampullary carcinoma (option B) is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination due to its anatomical location and its potential to obstruct both ducts.

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. No sensory deficit was found. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

  • Flexion at interphalangeal joint of thumb is caused by flexor pollicis longus which is supplied by anterior interosseous nerve, a pure motor branch of median nerve.
  • It branches from the median nerve in the proximal forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres muscle to run deep along the interosseous membrane.
  • From proximal to distal, it innervates the flexor pollicus longus (FPL), the index and long fingers of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP), and the pronator quadratus (PQ).
  • AIN syndrome is an isolated palsy of these three muscles.
  • It manifests mostly as pain in the forearm accompanied by a characteristic weakness of the index finger and thumb pincer movement.
  • Many cases of AIN syndrome arise secondary to transient neuritis, although nerve compression and trauma are known etiologies as well. 
  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is also a common cause of AIN injury.
  • The most common site of AIN entrapment/compression is the tendinous edge of the deep head of the pronator teres muscle. 
  • True AIN syndrome presentation will present with motor deficits only. 
  • No sensory changes appreciated. There are no numbness, tingling, or sensory deficits.
  • The patient will complain of having difficulty bringing the distal phalanx of the thumb and index finger together.
  • On a physical examination, the pinch grip test is positive. Rather than making the "OK" sign, the patient will clap the sheet between the index finger and an extended thumb.

 

 

  • The patient may also complain of having difficulty forming a fist or the inability to button their shirts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. The effect of trauma on the median nerve depends on the injury site and may involve the palm, forearm, arm, or axilla. The damage to the nerve can lead to motor, sensory, and vasomotor loss. Most injuries to the median nerve occur at the wrist. Traumatic injuries to the median nerve at the wrist can be due to wrist fractures. Nerve damage can range from compression to nerve contusion. On the wrist, the median nerve is exposed to cutting and penetrating injuries. The signs and symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome include thenar weakness, numbness in the radial 3 ½  fingers, and paresthesias, burning-like pain in the distribution of the median nerve. Symptoms can mimic the effects of an injury to the C6, C7 nerve roots. Symptoms are typically worse at night and awaken patients from sleep. There is no triceps or weakness in wrist extension. Carpal tunnel is also distinguishable with the Tinel and Phalen tests. A positive Tinel sign and positive Phalen maneuver are indicative of carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

Phalen’s Test for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

 

Option B. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve. The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve is a terminal branch of the ulnar nerve. It supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin on the ulnar side of the hand. The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist. Mechanism of injury includes local trauma, nerve impingement, lacerations at the wrist and Guyon canal cyst. Characteristic signs of injury to the ulnar nerve is the inability to grip paper between the fingers (Card Test) with ulnar claw hand deformity. The ulnar nerve injury can be characterized by flattening of medial border of forearm, loss of sensation at distal interphalangeal joints of 4th and 5th digit, loss of hypothenar eminence, loss of adduction of thumb, loss of abduction of fingers, clawing of 4th and 5th digits, and sensory, trophic and vasomotor changes.

 

 

Card Test (Palmar interossei – Loss of Adduction)

 

 

Ulnar Claw Hand Deformity

 

Option D. Posterior Interosseous Nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve, The deep branch of the radial nerve dives into the posterior forearm through the heads of the supinator to emerge as the posterior interosseous nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the posterior forearm. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve which innervates the extensor compartment of the forearm. It usually has an insidious onset, often presenting with weakness in finger and thumb extension. However, there is preservation in wrist extension due to the radial nerve innervated extensor carpi radialis longus. It is often self-limiting and resolves with conservative measures. However, symptoms that are refractory to non-operative treatment may require surgical decompression. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome can be present in Monteggia fractures or radial head fracture-dislocations. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnar is weakness. Depending on injury severity, there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In case of supracondylar humerus fracture, presenting with an inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, without any sensory deficit, the nerve most commonly injured is the anterior interosseous nerve, a terminal branch of the median nerve.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

When the initial Gridiron incision is converted to Rutherford Morrison incision, the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles are cut.

 

Gridiron incision is also known as McArthur’s incision. It is a muscle splitting incision used in open appendicectomy.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is useful in cases where the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. The lower end of the incision is located over McBurney's point and extends obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary. It involves cutting through the skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, underlying internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and peritoneum along the line of the incision.

 

The Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, located 2 cm below the umbilicus and centered on the midclavicular-mid-inguinal line.

 

The Pfannenstiel incision is an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

ECG monitoring for arrhythmias
Sedation being the side effect

questions.text: A patient was treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode in the hospital for 4 weeks. What is the main concern while considering his discharge from the hospital?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Suicidal risk

 

The main concern while considering the discharge of a patient who has been treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is Suicidal Risk.

 

Suicidal risk is a critical concern when discharging patients who have been treated for major depression. The risk of suicide can actually increase as the patient begins to recover, partly because they may gain more energy and motivation before their mood improves significantly. Further TCA are lethal in overdose. Therefore, ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support upon discharge is crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Need for Drug Monitoring: While some level of monitoring is advisable when a patient is on imipramine, especially for tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) blood levels in certain cases, it is not typically the primary concern at discharge for depression treatment.

 

Options B. ECG Monitoring for Arrhythmias: Although TCAs like imipramine can have cardiac side effects, including arrhythmias, and may warrant ECG monitoring, particularly in older adults or those with pre-existing heart conditions, it's not usually the primary concern at the point of discharge unless the patient has a known cardiac issue.

 

Options D. Sedation Being the Side Effect: While sedation can be a side effect of imipramine, it is generally not the main concern at discharge. The more pressing issue is the patient's mental health stability and safety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main concern when discharging a patient treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is the risk of suicide. This requires ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support to manage their mental health effectively after discharge.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the organism they are used for? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-F

 

The correct matches based on the given drugs and organisms:

 

  1. Praziquantal: This drug is primarily used for the treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm). Therefore, the correct match for Praziquantal is D (Tapeworms).
  2. Di Ethyl Carbamezine: This drug is the drug of choice for the treatment of filariasis, making A (Filaria) the correct match.
  3. Nitazoxanide: This drug is used for Cryptosporidium and also for Giardia. However, the drug of choice for Giardia is metronidazole or tinidazole, but Nitazoxanide is also effective against Giardia. Therefore, the correct match for Nitazoxanide is B (Giardia).
  4. Mebendazole: This drug is used for treating various nematodes, including Ascaris lumbricoides. Therefore, the correct match for Mebendazole is F (Ascaris lumbricoides).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug of choice for treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm) is Praziquantal.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole.
    • Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole
  • Drug of choice for all nematodes (see exceptions below) is albendazole (or Mebendazole)
    • Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin.
  • Nitazoxanide: DOC for Cryptosporidium and also used for Giardia (DOC is metronidazole and tinidazole)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/907
